subject: Re: [junit] Re: Any tools for Test Case generation?
msgSnippet: ... This is a fine point. Look at the kinds of tests that JTest can generate: simple boundary cases and unexpected exceptions. When we write code -- since we
messageBody:
>So said Mike Clark on 2003-06-10 --------------------
>Dave Astels wrote:
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
>>
>>>>So said hehaifengcn on 2003-06-10 --------------------
>>>>I have a project in which I want to some tools that can
>>>>automatically generate test case to exercise given execution path.
>>>
>>
>>>The idea of automatically generating tests is incompatible with the
>>>JUnit (and xUnit) philosophy. JUnit is a framework in which humans
>>>write tests; it is not a tool that writes tests.
>>
>>
>> Well said. I'll go farther and say that even a tool that generates a
>> set of JUnit (or xUnit) stubs to test all (or some selected subset)
>> the methods of a given class is incompatible with the philosophy.
>> JUnit is used to test behaviour. Behaviours and methods and not 1-1
>> or onto. A single behavior may encompass functionallity from several
>> methods, and a single method may embody several behaviours. Hmm..
>> there's an article in there.
>>
>>
>
>That being said, when I'm trying to add new functionality to legacy code
>that doesn't have tests, I'll gain confidence in any way possible. If I
>can easily run a tool that generates some amount of tests, then I'll use
>those tests as another anchor point. That is, I'll sic the tool on the
>existing code base, then continually run the tests it generates as I'm
>retrofitting the code. Better than nothin'.

This is a fine point. Look at the kinds of "tests" that JTest can generate: simple boundary cases and unexpected exceptions. When we write code -- since we are great programmers -- we don't screw up in such elementary ways; however, legacy code could have been written by *anyone*, so we might want to check such nonsense as NullPointerExceptions and dividing by 0. Those idiots could screw up in ways we couldn't imagine.

Beyond that, though, I'd rather write the tests myself. My boss may not like it, but the more I learn, the better I am at fixing the system.

>When I'm writing new code for a system built test first, I want to write
>all the tests by hand. In this case, tools actually impede the way I
>learn through testing.

I feel this whether it's a new or old system.

Take care.
